title: Developing and delivering neurocomputational models to bridge between brain and mind.
descriptions:
The proposed project, "Developing and delivering neurocomputational models to bridge between brain and mind," focuses on the field of Cognitive Neuroscience with the overarching goal of understanding the nature of mental processes and how they arise from neural machinery. By investigating complex mental behaviors, mapping neural systems and their functions, and developing methods to bridge brain and mental behavior, the project aims to establish the basis of neurological patients' impairments and improve clinical management and treatment.

Key components of the project include the convergence of methods and the development of a new type of neurocomputational model. Utilizing experimental psychology, behavioral neurology, in vivo neuroimaging, and allied technologies, the project will secure methods and tools for systematic bridging between cognitive science and systems neuroscience. By mimicking normal and impaired behavior and connecting neuroanatomy and cognition, the project will provide a novel formalism for bridging between brain and cognition.

Overall, this project will contribute to advancing our understanding of the relationship between the brain and the mind through the creation of neurocomputational models that reflect systems-level neuroanatomy and function. Through the utilization of computational models, the project aims to bridge the gap between brain and mind, ultimately improving clinical outcomes for neurological patients.

The proposed project, titled "Developing and delivering neurocomputational models to bridge between brain and mind," aims to advance the field of Cognitive Neuroscience by understanding the nature of mental processes and how they arise from neural machinery. By investigating complex mental behaviors and cognitive processes, mapping neural systems and their functions, and developing new methods and tools to bridge brain and mental behavior, this project seeks to establish the basis of neurological patients' impairments and improve clinical management and treatment.

The main activities of the project include the convergence of methods and the development of a new type of neurocomputational model. By utilizing experimental psychology, behavioral neurology, in vivo neuroimaging, and allied technologies, the project aims to secure methods and tools for systematic bridging between cognitive science and systems neuroscience. The ultimate goal is to provide a novel formalism for bridging between brain and cognition, forcing a convergence of results.

The utilization of computational models in this project will allow for the mimicry of both normal and impaired behavior, as well as the connection between neuroanatomy and cognition. Overall, this project seeks to create neurocomputational models that reflect systems-level neuroanatomy and function, with the ability to simulate detailed cognitive behavior.
